Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Transforming the Image of Computing to Increase Female Participation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project explores the reasons for under representation of women in the field of computer science (CS). The investigation will include a series of experimental studies. There are numerous theories that explain the gender inequality in CS. The main hypothesis of the study is that it is not the genetic predisposition or an unwillingness to put in late hours but the stereotypical image of CS that impinges upon women's ability to see themselves in the field. The research will examine the gender difference in CS as a function of social factors. A series of controlled behavioral studies will be conducted in which two orthogonal dimensions related to the image of computer scientists are independently manipulated: gender and stereotypicality (i.e., the set of stereotypes widely associated with the group, such as affinity for video games and social awkwardness). These will be conducted across three domains through which stereotypes of CS are communicated: the media, classroom environments, and peer interactions.
The study's findings will have impacts on STEM fields which are looking to increase their diversity. The impact of stereotypes across three age groups (college, high school, and middle schools students) will be tested. The study will lead to the development of a virtual psychology laboratory that can be used well beyond the project duration to study stereotypes. One primary goal of this study is to disseminate findings broadly to schools, universities and the general public so more positive educational environments can be developed to nuture the interest and aspirations of women to enter the STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Women obtain about half of all science undergraduate degrees, yet they earn fewer than 20% of computer science degrees (National Science Foundation, 2012). Across all age groups, females consider a future in computer science to a lesser extent than their male counterparts (Dryburgh, 2000). The work in this grant demonstrated that students’ stereotypes of the people in the field serve as a barrier to women’s participation in computer science, and further demonstrated how to change these stereotypes to encourage women’s participation.

 

Intellectual Merit

The research revealed that students describe computer scientists currently as being intensely focused on computers and socially awkward (Cheryan, Plaut, Handron, & Hudson, 2013). Women rate these stereotypes as more incompatible with the way they see themselves than do men (Cheryan, Plaut, Davies, & Steele, 2009; Cheryan, et al., 2013). As a result, when these stereotypes are salient, women express less interest in computer science than do men. However, this work further showed that computer science stereotypes are malleable. Altering the field’s prominent stereotypes using the media (Cheryan et al., 2013), role models (Cheryan, Siy, Vichayapai, Drury, & Kim, 2011), and computer science environments (Cheryan et al., 2009) caused women to express more interest in pursuing computer science. For instance, women who read a fabricated newspaper article stating that computer scientists no longer fit the “geeky” stereotype expressed greater interest in computer science than women who read that computer scientists continue to fit the stereotype (Cheryan et al., 2013). Exposure to these stereotypes reduces women’s sense of belonging with the people in the field (Cheryan, Meltzoff, & Kim, 2011; Cheryan et al., 2009). These effects extended to high school students as well (Master, et al., 2015).

This work also revealed that stereotypes of a field could be communicated simply by the way an environment was set up. When women were exposed to educational and corporate environments (real, imagined, or virtual) containing objects that were stereotypically associated with computer science (e.g., Star Trek posters, video games), they expressed less interest in computer science than when they were in environments that did not reflect current stereotypes (Cheryan, Meltzoff, et al., 2011; Cheryan et al., 2009; Master, et al., 2015).

This work has had a significant impact both within and outside of psychology. During the course of the grant, thirteen papers were published in top psychology and education journals, such as the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology and the Journal of Educational Psychology. The results have been presented at more than 17 conferences. Three of the papers have over 50 citations to date, and one of them (Cheryan, et al., 2009) has been cited more than 250 times to date.

 

Broader Impact

This work has had a broader impact in education and technology. Based on our findings, in 2014, the White House issued a press release announcing a design prize to change classroom environments. I went to the White House in December 2014 and shared this research with President Obama, Chief Technology Officer Megan Smith, Director of NSF France Cordova, among others. In response to learning about this work, high schools have changed their environments. Departments and companies have also changed their practices. For instance, the UW Computer Science and Engineering department remodeled their computer lab in 2010. Google also renamed their conference rooms.
